snippet: As Americans flock this year to outsider candidates, they are suddenly waking up to the reality that the process for picking the parties’ nominees involves ordinary voters in only an indirect way.
abstract: Voters in 2016 presidential primary are growing increasingly angry over convoluted nominee selection process that downplays influence of ordinary voters in favor of delegate support; delegate system, which was created to keep outsider candidates from nomination, is especially frustrating to supporters of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, many of who charge it is elitist and unfair.

byline.contributor: Jon Hurdle contributed reporting from Philadelphia and Nate Schweber from Bethpage, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: As Americans flock this year to outsider candidates, they are suddenly waking up to the reality that the process for picking the parties’ nominees involves ordinary voters in only an indirect way.

headline.main: As Campaigns Seek Delegates, Ordinary Voters Feel Sidelined
headline.print_headline: Primary Process Has Many Voters Feeling Sidelined
